sn8.5:1.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
sn8.5:2.1: “Mendicants, speech that has four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.
sn8.5:2.3: It’s when a mendicant speaks well, not poorly; they speak on the teaching, not against the teaching; they speak pleasantly, not unpleasantly; and they speak truthfully, not falsely.
sn8.5:2.4: Speech with these four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.”
sn8.5:2.5: That is what the Buddha said.
sn8.5:2.6: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn8.5:3.1: “Good people say well-spoken words are foremost;
sn8.5:3.2: second, speak on the teaching, not against it;
sn8.5:3.4: and fourth, speak truthfully, not falsely.”
sn8.5:4.1: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
sn8.5:4.2: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”
sn8.5:4.3: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
sn8.5:4.4: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
sn8.5:5.4: such speech is truly well spoken.
sn8.5:6.4: that bring nothing bad to others.
sn8.5:7.1: Truth itself is the undying word:
sn8.5:7.3: Good people say that the teaching and its meaning
sn8.5:8.1: The words spoken by the Buddha
sn8.5:8.3: for making an end of suffering:
sn8.5:8.4: this really is the best kind of speech.”
